We should hear from the spots that are closest to the brink.”

Terra said, “Friends, it is easy to see,
The ones living closest know best what should be.”
Sam nodded and grinned, “It’s like fixing a shed—
You ask the one using it, not someone instead.”

Ande thought, “Back home, in our garden each year,
We tend what we know and keep problems near.
If strangers decided how flowers should grow,
They might make up rules they don’t even know.”
Sam added, “And just like when I fix my kite,
The one who’s right here can get it just right.”

So each little section would pick a wise head,
To speak for their needs and share what was said.
Sam built a sign for each group to display,
With names of their leaders in bright, friendly way.

Flora flew up where the tall sunflowers swayed,
“We vote for the water line first to be laid!”
The stems gave a rustle, their golden heads bent,
Agreeing at once that her choice was well spent.
Sam drew a blueprint for fixing the flow,
“So we’ll all have water to help gardens grow.”

Scout hopped along from the bush full of berries,
“Our path must be cleared before wintertime hurries.”
He lifted his shears with a confident cheer,
“We’ll trim it all back so the way is kept clear!”
Sam grabbed a basket to carry the waste,
“And I’ll haul the trimmings to keep up the pace.”

Down by the pond, Terra nodded with grace,
“We’ll sweep the old lily pads out of this place.
When water is flowing and bright once again,
We’ll welcome back fish to their shimmering den.”
Sam fetched a net and gave Terra a wink,
“Let’s scoop them together before the sun sinks.”

Back at the gate, Buzz was happy to say,
“We’ll help one another in fair, steady way.
First sunflowers, then berries, the pond will be last,
Working together, we’ll finish up fast!”
Sam checked the list he had written so neat,
“Every job’s ready—this plan’s complete!”

“This way,” Ande smiled, “every voice can be heard,
Each job will get done, with no task left blurred.
When all lend a hand, the work flows like a stream,
And the garden can grow like a well-tended dream.”
Sam laughed, “And my checklist shows we’re on track—
We’ll finish the work without holding back.”

They fixed up the water, they pruned berry vines,
They cleared the small pond till it sparkled and shined.
Sam carted clippings and stacked them with care,
While friends worked together in fresh garden air.

At sunset, they gathered and looked all around,
At blossoms and berries and green grassy ground.
“We governed ourselves,” said Terra with glee,
“And our garden’s the best it could possibly be!”
Sam nodded, “It worked—local voices were heard.
That’s the best kind of plan for the garden and herd.”

Local decisions keep troubles away,
When neighbors and friends have the most they can say.
From garden to town, it works just the same—
Strong local voices keep freedom aflame.
“And teamwork,” said Sam, “makes the work light and fast—
So our garden will bloom and the joy will last.”

books.activity:
Discussion Prompt: Why might local government serve people better than distant government?
Activity: Pick a small local problem. Solve it together without waiting for higher authority. Draw a “Family Governance Map” showing who decides what in your home and community.
books.epilogue:
This story introduces Strong Local Self-Government, the 21st of 28 principles featured in Liberty’s Principles Pals. These principles are inspired by themes from The 5,000 Year Leap, a book by W. Cleon Skousen, which highlights the wisdom of keeping power close to the people.

“The way to have good and safe government is not to trust it all to one, but to divide it among the many, distributing to every one exactly the functions he is competent to.” —Thomas Jefferson

Local self-government teaches us that freedom is best preserved when decisions are made by those who understand local needs and share in the results. Just as gardeners know which plants need water or shade, communities thrive when people nearby solve problems together.

As you reflect with your child, consider questions such as:

• Why might neighbors or local leaders understand problems better than distant officials?
• Can you think of a time when your family solved a problem together without waiting for others to decide?
• What choices can children make at home that help the whole family?

By connecting everyday decisions to this principle, children see that freedom lasts when we work together locally, caring for our homes, families, and neighborhoods. Strong local voices keep liberty alive.

books.title: Ande and the Garden Rules
books.preface:
Welcome to the twenty-second book of the Freedom Garden series!
This series shares 28 adventures. Each adventure teaches a principle that helps freedom grow.
A principle is a rule that explains how things work. One of those principles is called the Rule of Law.
The Rule of Law means that everyone—leaders and citizens alike—must follow the same set of fair rules. No one is above the law.
Just like a garden thrives when everyone follows the same care instructions, a community thrives when rules are clear, consistent, and apply to all. Without shared rules, confusion and unfairness grow like weeds. But when rules are respected equally, freedom and fairness bloom for everyone.
Long ago, wise leaders taught that freedom cannot last if rulers can change the rules whenever they wish. They believed laws, not people’s moods, should guide decisions. That way, all are treated with fairness, from the smallest citizen to the highest leader.
Come join Ande, Sam, and their Freedom Garden friends as they discover how fair rules keep their garden—and their world—healthy, safe, and free!

pages.text:
One bright morning, skies so blue,
Ande skipped in—she had work to do.
Flora twirled with carefree cheer,
Buzz said, “The garden rules are clear!”

“Garden rules? What could they be?”
Buzz replied, “They help you and me.
Share the water, keep paths neat,
Take only what you need to eat.”

Flora giggled, “What’s the fuss?
A day without rules sounds fine to us!”
Ande frowned, “Let’s think this through—
What happens if no one follows through?”

Scout hopped high into the bed,
Squashing blooms beneath his tread.
“Oops!” he laughed, “They felt so soft.”
Flora’s glitter drifted aloft.

By midday, puddles spread and grew,
Some plants thirsted, others too few.
Paths were blocked, tools astray—
The garden’s joy had slipped away.

Buzz declared with steady tone,
“Rules protect what we all own.
Let’s repair and set things right—
Work together ‘til it’s bright.”

Paths were cleared, the water shared,
Beds rebuilt with extra care.
Flora’s sparkles danced in air,
Ande smiled—fair is fair.

Nanny Dolores came to see,
The garden blooming happily.
She read each rule out loud and clear—
Then followed them herself, sincere.
“Even those who lead,” she said,
“Must walk the path the rules have led.”

By dusk, the blooms stood tall again,
No one’s mood deciding when.
“Rules aren’t just to boss or sway—
They keep things fair for all each day.”

That night Ande wrote in her book,
Of all the lessons she had took:
“Rule of law is promise true—
I care for others, they care for you.”

books.activity:
Create your own set of garden rules!
Draw a picture of your garden, and write 3 rules to help keep it fair and beautiful for everyone.
books.epilogue:
This story introduces the Rule of Law, the 22nd of 28 principles featured in Liberty’s Principles Pals. These principles are inspired by themes from The 5,000 Year Leap by W. Cleon Skousen, which explains how clear, consistent laws protect liberty for all.

John Adams said it best: “We are a government of laws, and not of men.”

The Rule of Law reminds us that freedom survives only when rules are fair, public, and apply to everyone equally—leaders and citizens alike. No one is above the law.

As you reflect with your child, consider questions such as:

• Why is it important that rules apply to everyone, even leaders?

• How does following fair rules help people feel safe and respected?

• Can you think of a time when knowing the rules helped solve a problem fairly?

Just as healthy soil anchors strong roots, the Rule of Law anchors freedom. When families and communities live by fair and equal rules, liberty grows strong for generations to come.

books.title: The Garden Schoolhouse
books.preface:
Welcome to the twenty-third book of the Freedom Garden series!
This series shares 28 adventures. Each adventure teaches a principle that helps freedom grow.

A principle is a rule that explains how things work. One of those principles is called The Value of Education.
The Value of Education means that learning is the key to solving problems, protecting freedom, and helping communities grow strong.

Just like a garden needs water and sunlight to flourish, people need knowledge and understanding to keep their minds sharp and their choices wise.

Long ago, wise leaders taught that liberty cannot last if people remain ignorant. Thomas Jefferson said, “An educated citizenry is a vital requisite for our survival as a free people.” Without knowledge, citizens can be misled or lose their freedoms. But when children and families learn together, asking questions and seeking truth, freedom blossoms—just like flowers thriving under the sun.

Come join Ande, Sam, and their Freedom Garden friends as they discover how learning turns their garden—and their world—into a brighter, stronger place!

pages.text:
Sunbeams danced on blooms so bright,
Until a vine crept in the light.
Its shadow spread, the flowers drooped,
And over gates the tendrils looped.
“The plants can’t grow!” cried Buzz in fear,
“We’ll lose the garden we hold dear!”

Ande called to Sam nearby,
“Come quick! This vine will make plants die.”
Sam ran in with Scout the Hare,
And Flora fluttered through the air.
The friends all frowned at what they saw—
A creeping vine with hungry maw.

Nanny Dolores came with care,
Her apron pockets treasures rare.
“This vine is tricky, yes it’s true,
But learning shows us what to do.
A garden—like a town or school—
Grows stronger when we know the rules.”

“First step,” said Nanny, “learn its ways,
The habits formed in all its days.
Observe, record, ask what it needs,
For knowledge is the soil for deeds.
We’ll make this garden into class,
And watch the vine through hours pass.”

Flora mapped where sunlight lay,
With sparkles lighting up the way.
Scout dug down to find the root,
To learn what fed the creeping shoot.
Ande read how vines behave,
While Sam took notes on what they gave.

They found it drank both sun and dew,
And sipped from flowers’ nectar too.
“It takes too much,” said Sam, “not fair—
Like rules that give one group all share.”
“But if we guide, not chop away,
It might still grow the proper way.”

They built a list of what to try,
And hung it where all could spy.
“Step one—make space for light to fall.
Step two—share water with us all.”
“Step three—record what happens here,
So others learn each passing year.”

Buzz spread gold pollen in the air,
Flora’s glow showed shoots where to share.
Scout built a trellis, tall and wide,
To help the vine grow side by side.
Ande kept notes, her pencil fast,
For every fact could make change last.

They tried their plan for seven days,
Adjusting vines in gentle ways.
Some shoots grew straight, some curled anew,
But every test taught something true.
“Like citizens who cast their vote,
We learn, adapt, and change the note.”

Sam brought a chart to track the sun,
Ande made graphs of what they’d done.
Nanny explained, “This skill you gain
Will help in gardens, towns, or grain—
For knowing facts and keeping score
Helps guide good choices evermore.”

The vine grew tall, the flowers bloomed,
The garden’s space was now well-roomed.
No shade to steal the plants’ delight,
Each leaf and petal faced the light.
The friends all cheered, “We’ve done our best—
And learned enough to teach the rest!”

They hosted class beneath the tree,
Inviting creatures two and three.
Flora showed maps, Sam read aloud,
Ande explained to every crowd:
“When people learn, they see what’s fair—
And build a world where all can share.”

Scout told the tale of digging deep,
Of secrets roots would always keep.
Buzz taught the value of the bees,
And how they work with flowers’ needs.
The guests went home with seeds to sow,
And lessons they’d help others know.

Nanny gave Ande a book that shone,
“For every lesson you have grown.
When people learn, they see the way,
And keep their freedoms every day.”
Ande smiled, “I’ll keep this near—
Learning’s light will guide each year.”

The vine now climbed in gentle grace,
No more to steal another’s space.
The garden thrived, the friends all knew,
What careful learning helps us do.
“When we know, we grow,” Sam said with cheer,
“And that keeps freedom strong each year.”

books.activity:
Family Activity — Your Own Schoolhouse

Pick something you want to learn about together.
Research it in books or online.
Make a plan to use what you learned.
Share your results!

Discussion Prompt: How is solving a problem in the garden like solving a problem in your community?
books.epilogue:
This story introduces The Value of Education, the 23rd of 28 principles featured in Liberty’s Principles Pals. These principles are inspired by themes from The 5,000 Year Leap by W. Cleon Skousen, which highlights the wisdom of the Founders in creating a free and lasting republic.

James Madison reminded us: “Knowledge will forever govern ignorance; and a people who mean to be their own governors must arm themselves with the power which knowledge gives.”

Education gives children and families the tools to recognize truth, make wise decisions, and protect liberty. Just as healthy roots keep a tree standing tall, knowledge gives strength to our choices and helps freedom endure from one generation to the next.

As you reflect with your child, consider questions such as:

• How did learning help Ande and Sam solve their garden’s problem?

• Why did the Founders believe education was so important for freedom?

• What is something new your family can learn together this week?

By making learning a joyful part of everyday life, children see that freedom survives only when people value knowledge. Education is the sunlight of liberty.

books.title: Ande and the Garden Wall
books.preface:
Welcome to the twenty-fourth book of the Freedom Garden series!
This series shares 28 adventures. Each adventure teaches a principle that helps freedom grow.

A principle is a rule that explains how things work. One of those principles is called National Strength.

National Strength means that a free people must stay strong—not only with walls and shields, but also with courage, unity, and care for one another. A weak garden, or a weak nation, cannot stand tall against storms or troubles.

Just like a garden needs sturdy walls, deep roots, and helping hands to thrive, people need teamwork, patience, and preparation to protect their freedom.

Long ago, wise leaders taught that liberty does not survive unless citizens are strong in body, mind, and spirit. But when families practice courage, cooperation, and responsibility together, freedom flourishes—like flowers rising tall in the summer sun.

Come join Ande, Sam, and their Freedom Garden friends as they discover how building strength in their garden—and in their hearts—helps them keep freedom safe and strong!

pages.text:
The garden was peaceful, the air warm and sweet,
Bright blooms in a rainbow lined every seat.
Then Terra gasped, eyes open wide,
“A piece of the garden wall’s broken outside!”

“This wall keeps out critters and shields from the breeze,
Without it, we’ll lose all our flowers and peas!”
Ande frowned and said, “We’ll fix it today,
With teamwork and care, we’ll find the way.”

“Let’s all help!” called out Buzz with cheer,
“We’ll each take a job to get things clear!”
Scout hopped for stones, Flora fetched vines,
Buzz zipped for sap from the old garden pines.

Scout stacked them quickly—CRASH, they fell down!
Flora wove vines till they snapped with a frown.
“This is harder than I thought it would be,”
Said Flora, wings drooping, sadly to me.

“Strength,” Terra said, “needs patience and thought,
Not just hard work or stones that are brought.”
Ande drew plans while the others leaned near,
“We’ll fix it together—let’s make it clear.”

Scout placed each stone, Flora wove vines just right,
Buzz sealed the cracks, sticky sap shining bright.
Ande checked the plan, nodding with pride,
They worked as a team, all side by side.

The sun painted gold on the wall standing tall,
Flowers bloomed brightly along every wall.
“We did it!” cried Ande, “Together we’ve grown—
A strong wall to guard all the seeds we have sown.”

That night ‘neath a tree, Ande whispered so small,
“This wall reminds me we all need us all.”
Grandma agreed with a warm, gentle tone,
“That’s true for nations as much as our home.”

By lantern she wrote, “Strength’s not just might,
It’s sharing, it’s caring, it’s doing what’s right.”
She placed in her box—stone, vine, and sap—
A memory of teamwork all snug in her lap.

Rain tapped the wall but it held every stone,
The garden inside was safe, fully grown.
They smiled and knew what their hard work had done—
Protected the garden for everyone.

“This is our country,” said Grandma with cheer,
“Each of us helping will keep it secure.”
Ande walked proudly with friends by her side,
Knowing their care was the garden’s true guide.

“We kept it safe ‘cause we worked as a crew,
We planned, we prepared, and we all followed through.”
That’s real strength, Ande thought with a grin,
It starts with our hearts and it grows from within.

They promised to watch and repair any crack,
For walls, like friendships, need constant care back.
The garden would flourish for years yet to be,
Strong walls, strong hearts, keeping all free.

So remember the wall when winds start to blow,
Stand side by side, help your strength grow.
For gardens and nations both need the same—
Unity, courage, and love’s steady flame.
Family Compass: Build your own strong wall. Draw each part showing how it works and who helps. How can your family keep your “wall” strong?

books.activity: Build your own strong wall! Draw a picture of your garden wall and add details that show how each part works together to make it strong. Who will help build it?
books.epilogue:
This story introduces National Strength, the 24th of 28 principles featured in Liberty’s Principles Pals. These principles are inspired by themes from The 5,000 Year Leap by W. Cleon Skousen, which explains how freedom requires not just hope, but strength to endure.

“To be prepared for war is one of the most effective means of preserving peace.” — George Washington

Strength is more than might. It is courage to do what is right, wisdom to plan ahead, and care to protect what we value. Just as the garden wall protects flowers and vegetables from harm, a strong and united people protect their freedom for generations to come.

As you reflect with your child, consider questions such as:

How did Ande and her friends make the wall stronger?

What kinds of strength—physical, moral, or teamwork—help families stay safe and free?

Can you think of ways your family builds strength together every day?

By connecting the idea of strength to daily life, children can see that freedom lasts only when we work together to stay strong in every way. Strength is the guardian of liberty.

books.title: Ande and the Promise Pebbles
books.preface:
Welcome to the twenty-seventh book of the Freedom Garden series!
This series shares 28 adventures. Each adventure teaches a principle that helps freedom grow.

A principle is a rule that explains how things work. One of those principles is called The Burden of Debt.

The Burden of Debt means borrowing today takes away freedom tomorrow. It makes us trade our future choices for something we already used.

Just like a garden loses strength if we take too much from the soil, people lose freedom when they spend what they do not have. Wise leaders long ago warned that too much debt can chain both people and nations, leaving fewer choices for tomorrow.

But when families and communities learn to save, work steadily, and plan with care, freedom grows stronger—like seeds planted in rich soil that provide harvests for years to come.

Come join Ande, Sam, and their Freedom Garden friends as they discover how saving for tomorrow helps their garden—and their lives—stay free and full of promise!

pages.text:
Planting day, the soil was sweet,
Ande pressed seeds in tidy neat.
Sam stacked sticks with labels true,
Nanny hummed as breezes blew.

From ferny shade, the Pixies came,
"Promise Pebbles" was their name.
"Energy now, just give some back-
Tomorrow's time upon the track."

Ande took one, her row was done,
Her arms felt strong, the work was fun.
Sam grinned wide, "I'll take two more,
And finish twice what's planned in store!"

Next day dawned, her body slow,
The pebble's tug began to grow.
Sam stood ready, kite in hand,
But playtime shifted, not as planned.

The tug took games, the tug took walks,
It even claimed their story talks.
Sam sighed once and lowered the kite,
Tomorrow's debt had claimed her light.

Terra said, "What you borrow today,
Takes hours from tomorrow's play."
Nanny poured tea and gently spoke,
"Bind not tomorrow for today's small stroke."

"And I took one," Ande replied,
Terra nodded, "Yet tugs can hide."
Nanny tapped her cup and said,
"Even small pulls can grow and spread."

Flora called, "Grow berries bright,
They give you strength both fair and right."
Sam said, "I'll make a watering line,
With strings and washers-works just fine."

They worked, they rested, kept the pace,
Each berry shone with star-specked grace.
Ande returned what she had owed,
The pebble's pull no longer showed.

The wind blew in a sudden rain,
But Ande's time was hers again.
Sam tied planters by the rail,
Nanny's twine would never fail.

The rain passed by, the leaves stood tall,
The pebble quiet, no tug at all.
Sam's kite soared high in the sky,
Ande read as clouds rolled by.

Terra said, "Earned strength will stay."
Flora nodded, "It lights the way."
Nanny shared her steady tone,
"Save two. Spend one. Borrow none."

Ande painted the garden sign,
Sam drew a jar with circles fine.
The rule stood clear beneath the sun,
Save two. Spend one. Borrow none.

Pixies peered from shaded green,
Nods and waves, a gentle scene.
Sam's kite tail danced, Nanny poured tea,
Berry muffins for all to see.

Night fell soft, the garden deep,
Nanny watched them drift to sleep.
The stone dish empty by the door,
Tomorrow's time was theirs once more.

books.activity:
Pebble Jar Plan

Make three circles: Play, Learn, Help.
Each day, place three tokens. Save two. Spend one.
Keep your jar light. Borrow none. — Nanny Dolores
books.epilogue:
This story introduces The Burden of Debt, the 27th of 28 principles featured in Liberty’s Principles Pals. These principles are inspired by themes from The 5,000 Year Leap by W. Cleon Skousen, which shows how careful planning and thrift protect freedom.

"Rather go to bed without dinner than to rise in debt." — Benjamin Franklin

Debt limits choices, but saving opens doors. Just as Ande and Sam learned, borrowing from tomorrow weakens today's joy. By choosing to live wisely and save for the future, families and nations can protect freedom for generations.

As you reflect with your child, consider questions such as:

How did the Promise Pebbles in the story show the hidden cost of borrowing?

Can you think of a time when saving or waiting made something even better?

What small habits can families practice—like saving coins in a jar—that help keep tomorrow free?

By teaching thrift and responsibility, children can see that true freedom is not just having choices today, but keeping those choices alive for tomorrow. Debt is a burden, but wisdom and saving make liberty grow.

books.title: Ande and the Marketplace of Harmony
books.preface:
Welcome to the twenty-fifth book of the Freedom Garden series!
This series shares 28 adventures. Each adventure teaches a principle that helps freedom grow.
A principle is a rule that explains how things work. One of those principles is called Peace, Commerce, and Honest Friendship with All Nations-Entangling Alliances with None.
This principle means we can be friends and trade fairly with everyone, but we should avoid getting stuck in quarrels that don't belong to us. Just as a garden thrives when plants grow side by side without tangling each other's roots, people thrive when they build honest friendships without becoming trapped in others' conflicts.
Long ago, wise leaders like George Washington and Thomas Jefferson taught that lasting peace comes through fairness, trade, and goodwill-not through endless alliances or wars. When people practice honesty and kindness with all, they grow stronger and more free, just like flowers that share the sunshine together.
Come join Ande, Sam, and their Freedom Garden friends as they discover how harmony and fair exchange make their garden-and their world-peaceful and bright!

pages.text:
One sunny morn, with the garden awake,
Ande heard laughter by the lily-lined lake.
Sam held his basket, "What could it be?"
They followed the sounds past the tall blossom tree.

It's the Harmony Market! called Flora with cheer.
Where friends come to trade, all creatures appear.
Sam's eyes grew wide, "Let's see what they've made-
but first, tell me, Ande, what we've brought to trade?"

Terra explained, "It's a wonderful plan-
We share what we can, each giving a hand.
Bees bring their honey, rabbits bring greens,
Garlands from flowers, the prettiest seen."

Ande admired a honey jar's gleam.
Buzz hovered closer, sweet as a dream.
"To trade for this, what do you show?"
Sam checked their basket-nothing to go.

I'll draw the garden, its flowers, its streams!
Ande said brightly, eyes full of dreams.
A sunflower came and happily beamed,
Trading the jar for the sketch it had dreamed.

Soon more arrived with treasures to share-
Berries and garlands and stones bright and rare.
Sam helped deliver each trade with care,
And laughter and joy filled the warm garden air.

But then from the shade came a quarrelsome sound,
A bee and a rabbit both stood their ground.
That's my spot! No, mine! they cried with a frown,
Their spilled goods scattered all over the ground.

What happens to trade if we fuss and fight?
Ande asked softly, "Is that really right?"
Sam said, "Let's share-there's room for two.
We'll find a way that works for you."

Terra agreed with a slow, wise nod,
Peace is the path all traders have trod.
Work side by side, the market will grow,
When kindness and fairness are what we show.

So they built a stall for all to see,
"Bee and Rabbit's Treats"-a sign swung free.
Honey and carrots now shared with delight,
The market buzzed on from morning to night.

That evening glowed with lantern light's hue,
Trades still humming as the stars peeked through.
Peace and trade make the garden strong,
Ande told Sam as they strolled along.

Back home they found Nanny among the flowers,
Humming a tune in the twilight hours.
We worked together, all day long-
When friends unite, the bonds grow strong.

That's the heart of harmony, Nanny said.
Ande wrote her thoughts before going to bed:
Friendship with all, taking sides with none-
That's how true peace is always won.

The moon climbed high, the stalls closed tight,
The garden slept in the silver night.
The Harmony Market would come again,
When peace and trade walk hand in hand.

On their shelf they placed each treasure fair,
A garland, a stone, the honey jar there.
The market gave friends, Ande whispered low,
And that's the best trade we'll ever know.

books.activity: Create your own marketplace! What items would you bring to trade? Draw or list your items, and decide how you'd work with others to make your market peaceful and fun.
books.epilogue:
This story introduces Peace, Commerce, and Honest Friendship with All Nations-Entangling Alliances with None, the 25th of 28 principles featured in Liberty's Principles Pals. These principles are inspired by themes from The 5,000 Year Leap by W. Cleon Skousen, which highlights the wisdom of the Founders in shaping a free nation.
"Peace, commerce, and honest friendship with all nations-entangling alliances with none." -Thomas Jefferson
Peaceful trade and honest friendship create strength without conflict. Just as plants grow best when their roots are free yet share the same soil, people flourish when they respect one another's space while building trust and cooperation.
As you reflect with your child, consider questions such as:
• How did Ande and Sam learn to be friends with everyone without taking sides?
• Why does peace help communities grow stronger than quarrels?
• What does it mean to share fairly while still keeping your independence?
By practicing honesty, fairness, and friendly cooperation, children learn that lasting freedom comes not from conflict, but from peace and respect.

books.title: Ande, Sam, and the Circle of Seeds
books.preface:
Welcome to the twenty-sixth book of the Freedom Garden series!
This series shares 28 adventures. Each adventure teaches a principle that helps freedom grow.
A principle is a rule that explains how things work. One of those principles is called The Family as the Core Unit of Society.
The Family as the Core Unit of Society means that families are the foundation of strong communities and nations. Families teach values, foster responsibility, and help each person grow.
Just like a garden needs roots, soil, and sunlight to thrive, a family needs love, care, and teamwork to stay strong. Families give us the lessons of kindness, patience, and responsibility that help freedom grow.
Long ago, wise leaders taught that the strength of a nation depends on the strength of its families. When families are healthy, society blossoms. But when families weaken, freedom begins to fade.
Come join Ande, Sam, and their Freedom Garden friends as they discover how the seeds of family love grow into strength for the whole community!

pages.text:
One bright morning, near the trees,
Sam saw something in the leaves.
Ande bent and picked it out-
a pouch of seeds, without a doubt!

Seeds! cried Sam, But what kind grow?
To the herb bed, they did go.
Grandma smiled, They're Family Seeds, you see.
Plant them with love, and strong they'll be.

Where should we plant? asked Ande fast.
Grandma pointed, That patch will last.
Seeds need sunlight, water, and care-
teamwork too, so love can share.

Let's call our friends, said Sam with cheer.
Flora fluttered, I'm right here!
Scout and Buzz and Terra came-
each with tools to join the game.

They dug the soil, both deep and wide,
planted seeds all side by side.
Sam pressed the dirt with steady hands,
while Ande dreamed of flower bands.

Days went by, no sprouts in sight.
Sam frowned, Did we plant them right?
Terra said, It takes some time-
just like families, they slowly climb.

Each day they worked, from sun to shade,
weeding rows that Scout had made.
Flora chased the pests away,
Buzz brought nectar every day.

Ande poured with watering can,
Families grow with a good plan.
Sam laughed, And games are good too-
fun helps families blossom through!

Then one morning-what a sight!
Blooms appeared in morning light.
A circle formed, each bloom unique,
vines connecting, strong yet meek.

The Circle of Seeds! Grandma said.
Like a family, in green and red-
each one different, yet all belong,
tied together, growing strong.

They saw the flowers help the land,
holding soil with vine and strand.
Blossoms fed the bees that came,
leaves gave shade to sprouts by name.

That night they sat beneath the skies,
stars reflecting in their eyes.
Love and care make families grow,
said Ande soft, in evening's glow.

And when they do, said Sam with glee,
they make the world as good as can be.
Later, Ande wrote it down-
in her journal, safe and sound.

The Circle shone both far and near,
spreading joy throughout the year.
Our garden's strong, said Sam with pride.
Because we cared, and worked side-by-side.

Families thrive when each will share-
love and time to show they care.
Like a garden, they will bloom,
filling life with light and room.

books.activity: Plant your own Circle of Seeds! Draw your family or community as a garden. What kind of flowers would everyone be, and how would they help each other grow?
books.epilogue:
This story introduces The Family as the Core Unit of Society, the 26th of 28 principles featured in Liberty's Principles Pals. These principles are inspired by themes from The 5,000 Year Leap by W. Cleon Skousen, which highlights how strong families create strong nations.
"The foundation of national morality must be laid in private families." - John Adams
Families are the first schools of love, responsibility, and virtue. Just as roots anchor a tree, families anchor children with values that help them grow strong and free.
As you reflect with your child, consider questions such as:
• How did Ande and Sam learn that families grow stronger when everyone helps?
• What are some ways your family shows love and teamwork?
• How can families, like gardens, spread goodness to their whole community?
By seeing families as the building blocks of freedom, children learn that caring for and respecting family life helps everyone live in a society where liberty can blossom.

books.title: Ande and the Path of Possibilities
books.preface:
Welcome to the twenty-eighth book of the Freedom Garden series!
This series shares 28 adventures. Each adventure teaches a principle that helps freedom grow.
A principle is a rule that explains how things work. One of those principles is called Manifest Destiny.
Manifest Destiny means that people, when guided by hope and purpose, can build new opportunities that inspire others and create brighter communities.
Just like a garden stretches out when seeds are planted in new soil, freedom expands when families work with courage, kindness, and vision.
Long ago, wise leaders believed that America had a special role in showing liberty to the world-not by force, but by example, through building, sharing, and growing strong together.
Come join Ande, Sam, and their Freedom Garden friends as they step onto the Path of Possibilities and discover how working with purpose and hope can inspire others to do the same!

pages.text:
One bright morning, the garden shone,
Ande and Sam were not alone.
A brand-new path came into view,
Where will it lead? Let's see it through!

Grandma Dolores raised her hand,
This path can shape what you will plan.
It's called the Path of Possibility,
Where hope and work bring what will be.

What can we build? asked Sam with cheer.
Anything good, said Grandma near.
Bring hope, bring kindness, courage strong.
With these, your dreams will grow lifelong.

They packed up seeds and tools with care,
The glowing path led everywhere.
Flora, Scout, Buzz, Terra too-
Set off with Ande, Sam in view.

They found a field both wide and bare.
This land needs life to flourish there.
We'll plant, we'll build, and work all day,
To make it bloom in every way.

Flora cast seeds that caught the breeze,
Scout dug the rows with skill and ease.
Buzz marked the spots, Terra made walls,
Sam poured fresh water-hope recalls.

By evening light, the soil looked bright,
Green shoots peeked up, a joyful sight.
Ande wrote notes of what they'd done,
Sam laughed, Our work has just begun!

Days passed and colors filled the air,
The garden grew with tender care.
They watched with pride, their field turned strong,
They sang together hope's sweet song.

But storm winds came, the sky turned gray,
The plants bent low, the stones gave way.
Weeds crept inside, the rows looked wrong,
Oh no, cried Sam, It was so strong!

Next morning's sun revealed the test-
The flowers drooped, they'd lost their zest.
Ande looked sad, her notebook shook,
Sam sighed, Let's fix it-come and look.

Terra spoke slow, Let's plan ahead.
With deeper roots, no plants will dread.
Buzz added, Charts will keep us true.
Sam said, Windbreaks will help us too.

So Flora chose seeds tough and bright,
Scout dug neat rows with all his might.
Buzz tracked the sun, marked where it shone,
Sam built new walls of stone on stone.

The garden thrived, the blooms stood tall,
The veggies grew, no weeds at all.
Sam grinned, It's strong, it will not fall!
Ande wrote, Hope can guide us all.

Grandma arrived, her eyes so kind,
You've built with purpose, heart, and mind.
This field will shine for all to see,
An inspiration-just like thee.

That night they wrote by lantern light,
Work with hope makes futures bright.
Together we can build things strong,
And guide the world to sing along.

books.activity: Draw Your Own Path of Possibilities! What would you build to inspire others? Use hope, work, and care to make something strong for your garden or community.
books.epilogue:
This story introduces Manifest Destiny, the 28th of 28 principles featured in Liberty's Principles Pals.
These principles are inspired by themes from The 5,000 Year Leap by W. Cleon Skousen, which explains how America's Founders connected freedom with vision, responsibility, and opportunity.
"When a people work with purpose, guided by hope and goodness, they create a legacy that inspires generations." - Adapted from Founding Era ideals
Manifest Destiny reminds us that building with hope and purpose can create strong families, thriving communities, and a brighter nation. Just as the garden grew strong when Ande, Sam, and their friends worked together, we too can build a future worth sharing.
Reflection Questions:
• How did Ande and Sam show hope and teamwork on the Path of Possibilities?
• What happens when families or communities rebuild after a storm or challenge?
• What can you build today-in kindness, learning, or courage-that might inspire someone else tomorrow?
By connecting our choices to hope and purpose, children can see that freedom blossoms when each generation works to build something new and good. Manifest Destiny is the final reminder: liberty grows when we live to inspire others.

books.title: Ande and the Garden’s Forgotten Flowers
books.preface:
Welcome to the nineteenth book of the Freedom Garden series!
This series shares 28 adventures. Each adventure teaches a principle that helps freedom grow.
A principle is a rule that explains how things work. One of those principles is called Limited and Carefully Defined Powers.
This principle means that government should only use powers that are clearly written down, while all other powers stay with the people.
Just like a garden grows best when each helper knows their part, freedom grows when rules are clear and responsibilities are respected.
Long ago, wise leaders taught that power spreads like water-it seeps into every crack unless carefully guided. That's why they made sure to set boundaries, so liberty would not be drowned by too much control.
Come join Ande, Sam, and their Freedom Garden friends as they discover how clear rules help everyone bloom in their own bright way!

pages.text:
The garden was glowing in bright morning light,
But something seemed wrong, though it looked mostly right.
Why are those flowers all drooping that way?
Ande asked softly, Did someone forget them today?

Those are Forgotten Flowers, Terra replied,
They've heard so many voices, they can't decide.
Too many creatures give orders each hour,
And now they're unsure of their own growing power.

Who's in charge here? asked Ande with care,
Buzz rolled out a scroll that trailed through the air.
It's the Garden Rules List, he said with a hum,
But it's so very long, I forget where it's from!

The bees tell them when, and the butterflies how,
The rabbits say where, and they must listen now.
No one has asked what the flowers might need,
They're tangled in orders they never agreed.

Sam crossed his arms, That's too many chiefs,
No wonder they're hanging their petals like leafs.
Too many bosses can muddle the way,
We need one clear plan we can all obey.

Flora swooped down in a glittering twirl,
In a healthy garden, each helper and girl
Knows just what to do and then steps aside,
So flowers can grow with their own kind of pride.

Ande pulled out her journal, We'll write this all down.
I'll draw the borders! said Sam with a frown.
I'll sketch where each helper should work and should stay,
And label the paths so no one's in the way.

They called all the friends-the bees and the rest,
Ande read from her journal: Here's what works best.
Bees buzz and bring pollen, the butterflies glide,
The rabbits keep roots safe, and flowers decide.

Sam held up his map with neat colored lines,
Follow these paths and we'll all do just fine.
The bees have their zone, the butterflies too,
The flowers can stretch where the sunlight comes through.

The flowers perked up as the list became clear,
They swayed with relief now that freedom was near.
No more confusion, no orders to chase,
Each one could grow at its own gentle pace.

The blooms stood up taller, their colors shone bright,
Petals spread wide to drink in the light.
Freed from the tangle, they reached for the sky,
And bees hummed approval as they drifted by.

Clear rules and freedom, said Sam with delight,
Are just what they needed to grow in their might.
Too much control turns the garden all gray,
But the right kind of help lets joy lead the way.

Yes, Terra nodded, Control has a cost,
And too many voices can leave choices lost.
When roots have their space and the leaves have the sun,
The flowers can grow till the day's work is done.

Ande closed her journal, It's just like our clan-
We've rules in our home, but as much freedom as we can.
It's how we all learn to be thoughtful and strong,
While still knowing where the rules belong.

The garden now glowed in the soft evening hue,
Each bloom stood proud in its own shape and view.
The Forgotten Flowers weren't wilted or small-
They were free to be fully themselves, after all.

books.activity: Family Compass Activity - Make two lists: Powers We Give to Parents and Powers Kids Keep for Themselves. Discuss why some powers should be limited and others retained. Create a Family Power Charter and revisit it as children earn more freedoms.
books.epilogue:
This story introduces Limited and Carefully Defined Powers, the 19th of 28 principles featured in Liberty's Principles Pals. These principles are inspired by themes from The 5,000 Year Leap, a book by W. Cleon Skousen, which explains how liberty is protected when power is clearly limited.
"The powers delegated by the proposed Constitution to the federal government are few and defined. Those which are to remain in the State governments are numerous and indefinite." - James Madison, Federalist No. 45
Just as flowers thrive when helpers keep to their roles, people thrive when powers are limited and freedom is preserved. Clear rules keep balance, protect liberty, and help communities grow strong.
As you reflect with your child, consider questions such as:
• Why is it important that government powers are written down and limited?
• How did Ande and Sam help the Forgotten Flowers by setting clear rules?
• What rules in your family give structure while still leaving room for freedom?
By connecting boundaries and freedom, children can see that liberty survives when powers are carefully defined-and when people are trusted to grow in their own light.
